text.eng: Please click Run.
Please click Play.
Heat Lamp
Metal Mesh
Vinyl
Your science class has a green iguana named Iggy.\n\nIggy lives in a very large home that is made of metal mesh. The home is in the science classroom.
Some of your classmates have noticed problems with Iggy's behavior. He has a good home, but he could be happier!\n\nYour job is to learn about the problems and explore ways of solving them.
Iggy's cage is on a table in a dark area of the classroom.
The cage is made of metal mesh and the cage floor is made of vinyl.
A heat lamp is at the top of the cage. The lamp is always on.
Now look at Iggy's behavior in his home. Click Run to see his behavior over the course of a day.
When you have finished watching the video, click Next.

You and your classmates do more research and conclude that Iggy is awake and active at night because even though the classroom is dark at night, the heat lamp gives off lots of light.\n\nOne of your classmates makes some suggestions to make Iggy's home darker .
Let's turn off Iggy's heat lamp at night so it is dark in his cage.
Instead of the lamp we have in Iggy's cage now, let's use a special ceramic heat lamp that gives off heat but no light.
Yes, this will work.
No, this will not work.

Green iguanas are among the largest lizards in the Americas, averaging around 6 feet and weighing about 20 pounds! They are challenging to care for because they are adapted for survival in their native habitat.

They live in warm, very humid rain forests in places like Central America. They need the moist air in the rain forests. They are adapted to get moisture mostly from the humid air, not by drinking.

To be active and digest their food, iguanas must lie still in very hot sun. They need high temperatures. Since they are adapted to get heat from the Sun above, they are not good at absorbing heat on the lower part of their bodies.

They spend their days in tree branches, moving from warmer areas... ...to cooler areas to keep their bodies at the right temperatures. Pet iguanas must be able to move from warmer to cooler areas in their cages.

Iguanas usually live near water and are excellent swimmers.

They are vegetarians; they eat only leaves, flowers, and fruit.

Iguanas are active during the day and sleep at night. This means they do best with light in their cages in the day and darkness at night.

Before you solve Iggy's problems, you need to learn more about iguanas.\n\nWatch the short animation about iguanas. The film will give you information about iguanas to help you make changes to Iggy's home.
Review the iguana facts below that you learned from the animation.
Iguanas need very moist air and high temperatures.
Iguanas control their body temperature by moving in and out of warmer and cooler areas.
Iguanas are adapted to absorb heat from above.
Iguanas need 12 hours of darkness at night and 12 hours of strong light in the day.
The iguana facts will help you solve the problems with Iggy's home. You will be able to view these facts at any time.
Your classmates noticed two strange things about Iggy's behavior. Iggy's strange behavior means that there is probably something wrong with his home.
PROBLEMS
Iggy is always hanging on to his heat lamp! He does not want to be anywhere else.
The classroom's Iggy Webcam shows that Iggy is awake and active at night.
Let's start by trying to solve problem 1.\n\nIggy is always hanging on to his heat lamp! He does not want to be anywhere else.
Based on the iguana facts, what is the most likely reason Iggy is hanging on to his heat lamp?
Iggy likes being high up in his cage.
Iggy's home lacks moisture.
Iggy's home is too cold for him.
Iggy is not getting enough to eat.
Answer the question and click Submit.\nClick Iguana Facts to review facts about iguanas.
You and your classmates do some research and learn that Iggy is clinging to his heat lamp because his home is too cold.
Below are some changes that could be made to Iggy's cage.
Move Iggy's branch closer to his heat lamp.
Add a stronger heat lamp to Iggy's cage.
Add a large rock for Iggy to lie on.
Put a blanket at the bottom of Iggy's cage.
Click the change on the left that would most likely help with the problem of Iggy's home being too cold. Look at the facts about iguanas to help with your decision.
Explain how this idea would solve the problem and why it would work better than the other options. Be sure to refer to any relevant Iguana Facts in your response.
Click one of the choices on the left and type your explanation. Click Iguana Facts to review facts about iguanas. When you are finished, click Submit.
Your classmates agree that the best idea is to add a more powerful heat lamp to Iggy's cage. This should make his cage warmer.

Before you test to see if this is true, let's turn to problem 2. The classroom's Iggy Webcam shows that Iggy is awake and active at night. You have learned that iguanas need to sleep at night to be healthy.\n\nClick Next to continue.
Based on your observation of Iggy's behavior, what fact about iguanas is related to Iggy's second problem (Iggy is awake and active at night) ?"
Iguanas need very moist air.
Iguanas absorb heat from above.
Iguanas need to move in and out of warmer and cooler areas.
Iguanas need 12 hours of light and 12 hours of darkness.
Answer the question and click Submit.
You and your classmates do more research and conclude that Iggy is awake and active at night because even though the classroom is dark at night, the heat lamp gives off lots of light.
One of your classmates makes some suggestions to make Iggy's home darker.
Let's turn off Iggy's heat lamp at night so that it is dark in his cage.
Instead of the lamp we have in Iggy's cage now, let's use a special ceramic heat lamp that gives off heat but no light.
Using the Iguana Facts, evaluate each of the ideas. Choose whether or not the idea will work and explain why.
Type your answers in the boxes on the left. Then click Submit.
One of your classmates sees a product that could help solve Iggy's problem with too much light at night.
NEW! RepLife DAY-TO-NIGHT TIMER
The RepLife timer is a day-to-night dual timer device that provides complete 24-hour lighting cycles from dawn to nighttime. It has the following features.
8 outlets
4 independently operated timer-controlled outlets
4 constant-power outlets
On/Off switch
2 timer dials
3-foot heavy-duty power cord
Another classmate brings in the special ceramic heat lamp.
RepLife 60-Watt Ceramic Infrared Heat Emitter
Emits heat but no light for all types of reptiles!
You and your classmates now have
the RepLife timer;
Iggy's heat lamp; and
the RepLife ceramic heat lamp that gives off heat but no light.

Review the information about the RepLife timer and the RepLife ceramic heat lamp using the tabs on the left. Explain how to solve Iggy's sleeping problem with these materials. In your explanation, be specific about how each piece can be used to help solve the problem.
Review each approach by clicking the tabs on the left. Then type your answer and click Submit.
Timer
Ceramic Heat Lamp
You and your classmates think that using both Iggy's heat lamp and the ceramic heat lamp with the RepLife timer can help to solve Iggy's sleeping problem.
Now, test whether the changes to Iggy's home have solved problems 1 and 2 (cold home and not sleeping at night). Click Run to see the results of
using a new, stronger heat lamp; and
using the new RepLife timer and ceramic heat lamp.
Iggy is now sleeping at night, but you and your classmates see that Iggy is still clinging to his heat lamp during the day.
This means the temperature is still not high enough for him in the daytime. The first problem is not solved!
Right now, Iggy's home is made entirely of metal mesh, except for the vinyl floor and wood frame.
Your class decides to try replacing the metal mesh on the sides and back of Iggy's home with clear plastic panels. Doing this may keep more heat in the home. You call this design option 1.
Now click Run to see how well option 1 works for Iggy.
Based on Iggy's behavior, does option 1 work to solve Iggy's cold home?
Yes, this will work.
No, this will not work.
Explain your answer based on what you observed.
Answer the question and click Submit. You may click Run to observe Iggy's behavior again.
One of your classmates is taking an engineering class. She is studying how air of different temperatures moves in our homes and other structures we build, such as greenhouses.
She shares a greenhouse simulation from class that she thinks is relevant to solving Iggy's problem. Click Run to view the animation.
Compare option 1 to your classmate's simulation.
Based on the simulation, explain why adding plastic sides does NOT make Iggy’s cage warm enough. Be specific about the features of Iggy’s cage in relation to the simulation.
Review each approach by clicking the tabs on the left. Then type your answer and click Submit.
Greenhouse Simulation
option 1
option 2
You and your classmates decide that replacing the top of the cage with plastic is probably the best way to retain warm air. This new plan (replacing the sides, back, AND top) is called option 2.
Click Run to see how well option 2 works for Iggy.
You and your classmates observe that option 2 works!
Based on your observations, why does option 2 keep Iggy's home warmer than option 1 does?
There is more plastic in option 1 than in option 2.
More cold air is trapped in Iggy's home in option 1 than in option 2.
Warm air is prevented from escaping out the top in option 2.
More light is trapped in option 2 than is trapped in option 1.
Review each approach by clicking the tabs on the left. Then answer the question and click Submit.
One of your classmates has done some research about iguanas and is worried that Iggy may get dehydrated, meaning his body will not get enough moisture.
Based on what you have learned in this task about iguanas, which of these two items is best at preventing Iggy from getting dehydrated?
Another bowl of water in his new home
An automatic water-misting system in his new home
Explain why, referring to the iguana facts.
Answer the questions and click Submit.
Explain your answer.
Take another look to see if you and your classmates have solved Iggy’s problems. Click Run to see.
Thank you for your work.
Iggy is much more comfortable in his home now.
